Transformation Middle States Self-Study NYU Merger Past, Present, Future Giving                                          Home / Academics / Departments / Technology Management and Innovation                                                      Real world , hands-on learning in what it’s like to actually start a company. An entrepreneurial experience with all of the pressures and demands of an early stage startup.   Summer 2015 MG-GY 9781   Selected Topics in Management: Lean Launchpad    Units: 1.5 | Section: BZ | Class: 4639 | Date: Mon. Aug. 24th, 2015 through Fri. Aug. 28th, 2015 | Location: NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering, Rogers Hall RH 474, located in Brooklyn|   About the course   What is 5-day Lean LaunchPad?   5-day Lean LaunchPad is a practical class –a lab, not a “book” class - to give teams of students real world experience in how to turn an idea into a business. It is a 1.5 credit graduate level course offered from August 25-29 at NYU.   You’ll work in teams, getting your hands dirty talking to customers, partners, and competitors, as you encounter the chaos and uncertainty of how a startup actually works. It is a highly intensive, experiential class comprised of team presentations, customer interviews, and feedback from startup experts.   Each day will be a new adventure outside the classroom as you test each part of your business model and then share your hard earned knowledge with the rest of the class.   Who is this class for?      All NYU graduate students are eligible to apply (Masters, PhD, JD, MD).    You must apply to this course as part of a team (2-4 members per team).    All teams must enter the course with a startup idea they’d like to pursue.     What should you expect?      Five intense days of primary customer research/interviews and team presentations, guided by best practices in entrepreneurship education.    Feedback from successful entrepreneurs and investors from the NYU and NYC startup community, including Steve Blank.    Startup culture – fast paced, direct, open, and tough.     This class is not about:      Lecture-style presentations by the faculty.    Researching online or in the library.    Writing a business plan.    Creating a PowerPoint slide deck for a VC presentation.    Building the “hot-idea” you have in mind.     Application process and key dates   Prospective students will be granted registration from the NYU Polytechnic Records and Registration Office if they present fully completed and signed forms described in Step 5 below.   Step 0    Deadline: *ASAP*   First, find out if you’ll get 1.5 graduate credits for this course towards your degree and if you are allowed to register by your program. Click here for the Registration Pre-Approval Form and visit your school representatives, so you’ll know!   Step 1    Deadline: 5/18    Express interest by completing this form and indicating your availability for an info session / team hunt event.   Step 2   Attend an info session/team hunt event. You are required to attend at least one of the six info sessions to be apply to the course. Info sessions will be held at the Leslie eLab (e) and School of Engineering Greenhouse (g).    Event dates, times and locale   3/24: 2-4 pm (e)   4/7: 2-4 pm (e)   4/16: 5:30-7:30pm (e)   4/22: 3-5 pm (e)   5/7: 2-4 pm (g)   5/11: 10-12 pm (e)   5/18: 2-4 pm (g)   Step 3    Deadline: 5/29   Complete this application .    Note: One application per team.   Step 4: TEAM INTERVIEW    Timeframe: 5/1 - 6/26   Teams selected for the next round are required to attend an in-person ~15 min interview with a review committee. During the interview, the entire team will present their startup idea and answer questions about why they want to participate in the course.   Step 5: REGISTRATION FOR THE COURSE    Deadline: 7/3   5a. Teams selected for the course will be emailed and instructed for members to officially register individually.   5a1. The registration process requires that each student receive written permission from their program advisor, their bursar, and their registrar using the Registration Pre-Approval form in Step 0.   5a2. Lindsey Gray LM150@nyu.edu must sign an NYU Add/Drop form . She will review your Registration Pre-Approval Form and email both back to you.   5a3. Then, either bring in or email both forms together to NYU Poly’s Records & Registration Office (RRO) in 6 Metrotech Center, JB158, B'klyn, NY 11201 attn.: Wanda Green wg448@nyu.edu (718-260-3146). Incomplete forms will not be processed.   5b. If any team member does not register before the first day of class, all remaining members of that person’s teams will be automatically dropped from the course after the first day. To remain in the course, you can request reassignment to another approved team done in writing and submitted to the MG9781 Selected Topics in Management: Lean Launchpad instructor(s). By becoming a part of that new team you are subject to all conditions as part of that team. If no reassignment is possible, you will have to drop the course using the NYU Add/Drop Form (see 6d below).   Step 6: PARTICIPATION IN THE COURSE    Timeframe: 8/24-8/28   6a. If any team member chooses to drop the course once it has begun, as long as there are at least two team members remaining the team can continue on in the course. If only one team member remains, that person can request reassignment to another team in the class. The request for reassignment must be done in writing and submitted to the MG9781 Selected Topics in Management: Lean Launchpad instructor(s) for their approval. By becoming a part of that new team you are subject to all conditions as part of that team. If no reassignment is possible, you will have to officially drop or withdraw from the course. Use an NYU Add/Drop Form (see 6d below).   6b. Attendance is mandatory for each of the 5 days of the course - Aug 24, 25, 26, 27 and 28, 2015. If you miss more than 30 minutes of any class, you will be deregistered from the course and your team members may also be de-registered. The MG9781 Selected Topics in Management: Lean Launchpad instructor(s) will inform the Dept. Of TM&I of any de-registration. Force major does not apply for this course.   6c. Each team must have a completed ‘business model canvas' to submit by the beginning of Day 1 of this class (8/24/15). An explanation of the canvas and how to complete it will be shared with you in advance of the first day to guide you. Failure to complete this assignment for the first day of class will results in all team members being deregistered from the course.   6d. Drop/Withdraw. I f you elect to drop this course, you must do so by emailing a completed NYU Add/Drop form by Monday Aug 8/24 at 11:59pm to receive 100% tuition reimbursement Lindsey Gray. If you withdraw between Tuesday 8/25 and Thursday 8/27 you will receive a W grade and 0% tuition reimbursement. Email or bring an NYU Add/Drop Form to NYU Poly (RRO) in 6 Metrotech Center, JB158, B'klyn, NY 11201; attn.: Wanda Green wg448@nyu.edu .   6e. Grades. The grading policy for this course is described in detail in the syllabus. You will be graded as a team – all team members will receive the same grade. You must consult with your particular graduate Program Director to confirm whether or not this course will count towards your graduate degree (see Step 0).   For more details about the application process, see here . For more information, visit the FAQs . Still have questions? E-mail Lindsey Gray LM150@nyu.edu .   About Steve Blank   Steve Blank is a Silicon Valley serial-entrepreneur and academician based in Pescadero, California. Blank is recognized for developing the Customer Development methodology, which launched the Lean Startup movement. He has spent over thirty years in the high tech industry, and founded or worked at eight startup companies, four of which have gone public. He is a consulting associate professor of entrepreneurship at Stanford and lectures at the University of California Berkeley, California Institute of Technology and Columbia.    Learn more about Steve and read about past 5-day LLP classes . Majors and Minors, College of Arts and Science | NYU                                                 Navigation       College of Arts and Science                 About Arts and Science | Departments and Programs | The Faculty       About the College | Programs | Students | Admissions | Alumni               Home > Academic Programs > Majors and Minors         Majors and Minors       In addition to the majors listed below, the College of Arts and Science hosts over 60 minors. CAS students also have access to over 40 minors across NYU's other  undergraduate schools. CAS students interested in a cross-school minor should review our cross-school minor policies and FAQ page . To request declaration of a CAS major or minor, CAS students should visit the host department. To request declaration of a cross-school minor,   CAS students should complete the online Minor Application available in their Albert Student   Center. Students may also use the Minor Application in Albert to request cancellation of a CAS or cross-school minor. By becoming a part of that new team you are subject to all conditions as part of that team. If no reassignment is possible, you will have to officially drop or withdraw from the course. Use an NYU Add/Drop Form (see 6d below).   6b. Attendance is mandatory for each of the 5 days of the course - Aug 24, 25, 26, 27 and 28, 2015. If you miss more than 30 minutes of any class, you will be deregistered from the course and your team members may also be de-registered. The MG9781 Selected Topics in Management: Lean Launchpad instructor(s) will inform the Dept. Of TM&I of any de-registration. Force major does not apply for this course.   6c. Each team must have a completed ‘business model canvas' to submit by the beginning of Day 1 of this class (8/24/15). An explanation of the canvas and how to complete it will be shared with you in advance of the first day to guide you. Failure to complete this assignment for the first day of class will results in all team members being deregistered from the course.   6d. Drop/Withdraw. I f you elect to drop this course, you must do so by emailing a completed NYU Add/Drop form by Monday Aug 8/24 at 11:59pm to receive 100% tuition reimbursement Lindsey Gray. If you withdraw between Tuesday 8/25 and Thursday 8/27 you will receive a W grade and 0% tuition reimbursement. Email or bring an NYU Add/Drop Form to NYU Poly (RRO) in 6 Metrotech Center, JB158, B'klyn, NY 11201; attn.: Wanda Green wg448@nyu.edu .   6e. Grades. The grading policy for this course is described in detail in the syllabus. You will be graded as a team – all team members will receive the same grade. You must consult with your particular graduate Program Director to confirm whether or not this course will count towards your graduate degree (see Step 0).   For more details about the application process, see here . For more information, visit the FAQs . Still have questions? E-mail Lindsey Gray LM150@nyu.edu .   About Steve Blank   Steve Blank is a Silicon Valley serial-entrepreneur and academician based in Pescadero, California. Blank is recognized for developing the Customer Development methodology, which launched the Lean Startup movement. He has spent over thirty years in the high tech industry, and founded or worked at eight startup companies, four of which have gone public. He is a consulting associate professor of entrepreneurship at Stanford and lectures at the University of California Berkeley, California Institute of Technology and Columbia.    Learn more about Steve and read about past 5-day LLP classes . Majors and Minors, College of Arts and Science | NYU                                                 Navigation       College of Arts and Science                 About Arts and Science | Departments and Programs | The Faculty       About the College | Programs | Students | Admissions | Alumni               Home > Academic Programs > Majors and Minors         Majors and Minors       In addition to the majors listed below, the College of Arts and Science hosts over 60 minors. CAS students also have access to over 40 minors across NYU's other  undergraduate schools. CAS students interested in a cross-school minor should review our cross-school minor policies and FAQ page . To request declaration of a CAS major or minor, CAS students should visit the host department. To request declaration of a cross-school minor,   CAS students should complete the online Minor Application available in their Albert Student   Center. Students may also use the Minor Application in Albert to request cancellation of a CAS or cross-school minor. Accelerated Bachelor's-Master's Programs, College of Arts and Science | NYU                                                  Navigation       College of Arts and Science                 About Arts and Science | Departments and Programs | The Faculty       About the College | Programs | Students | Admissions | Alumni               Home > Academic Programs > B.A./M.A. Programs         Accelerated Bachelor's-Master's Programs       There are several ways that CAS students may begin earning credit   towards a Master's degree while still pursuing undergraduate studies.   Our accelerated, dual degree programs allow students to complete a   Master's in less time and at a lower cost than is normally required.   Students in these programs begin graduate coursework while still in CAS   and then apply that coursework towards designated Master's programs in   NYU's Graduate School of Arts and Science , Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public  Service , and Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development . Please   click on the links below to learn more about these unique time and   cost saving study options.  Before applying to one of the programs below, please meet with a Bachelor's-Master's advisor to discuss the application process and your academic plan:  Bachelor's-Master's Walk-In Advising Hours   Tuesdays, 12:00pm - 1:00pm Fridays, 11:00am - 12:00pm *NO HOURS FRI, MAY 1* with Scott Statland @ the Academic Resource Center (ARC) 18 Washington Place (check-in at front desk) ~ Mondays, 11:30am - 12:30pm Thursdays, 3:00pm - 4:00pm with Samantha Dillard @ the Preprofessional Advising Center Silver Center, 31 Washington Place, Room 901 (check-in at front desk) ~ or by appointment (click here to schedule)  Accelerated Bachelor's-Master's Program (CAS & GSAS)  Program Summary :   Students admitted to this program complete at least a quarter of required Master's degree credits while still undergraduates (these credits do not   count towards the Bachelor's degree). In the graduate portion of the   program, students receive a scholarship covering up to 50% of   tuition and registration fees for one year, during which time they can finish the remainder of   the Master's degree. SP15 Priority Application Deadline : March 2, 2015. Late applications are accepted on a rolling basis, though   not all departments can accept late applications. Please contact us to inquire further about your program of   interest. Questions? : Visit us during walk-in advising hours (schedule above) or write to cas-gsas-group@nyu.edu.      BA-MA and Accelerated MA Teacher Education Programs (CAS & Steinhardt)    Program Summary :     Students in selected CAS majors (Biology, Chemistry, English, History,   Mathematics, and Physics) can complete both their Bachelor's degree and a   Master's degree in Teaching (grades 7 - 12) in just 5 years. In   addition to saving money by completing the MA at an accelerated pace,   students in this dual degree program receive a generous scholarship   toward the MA degree. The scholarship typically covers 30% of graduation   tuition and may cover more depending on the program of study and   availability of external funds.       SP15 Pre-Application Deadline : We will accept pre-applications on a rolling basis following the March 17 priority deadline. Questions? : Visit us during walk-in advising hours (schedule above) or write to cas-steinhardt-group@nyu.edu.  Accelerated BA-MPA & BA-MUP Programs (CAS & Wagner) Program Summary :   Students pursue a Bachelor of Arts (BA) from the College   of Arts and Science and begin coursework towards a Master of Public Administration (MPA) or   Master of Urban Planning (MUP) from the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School   of Public Service. This program combines the benefits of a broad   liberal arts education at the undergraduate level with a professional   education at the graduate level. SP15 Pre-Application Deadline : We will accept pre-applications on a rolling basis following the March 17 priority deadline. Questions? : Visit us during walk-in advising hours (schedule above) or write to cas-wagner-group@nyu.edu.                     Welcome!
